intro: Leucothoe revoluta, commonly known as the mountain laurel, is a deciduous shrub native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family and is characterized by its dense, upright growth habit and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant produces clusters of white or pale pink flowers in the spring, which are followed by bright red berries in the fall. Its leaves are elliptical, leathery, and often have a slight waxy coating. Leucothoe revoluta thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland habitats.
